intro: Pepinia mituensis, commonly known as the African ghost flower, is a flowering plant native to parts of sub-Saharan Africa. It belongs to the family Acanthaceae and is characterized by its striking, showy inflorescences that resemble ghostly shapes. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and thrives in arid or semi-arid environments. Its leaves are opposite and often have a velvety texture, while its flowers come in shades of pink, purple, and white. Due to its unique appearance and habitat, it is of interest to botanists and horticulturists alike.
